data: One in a Million Free School

Our school is one of the most popular in the district. The number of students has increased by one third over the last decade
A survey of parents has shown a high level of satisfaction with the work done by the Teaching Staff (4.6 on a scale of 0 to 5), however, student motivation was lower at 3.35 which is why we will concentrate on improving that over the next 2 years. We will do this by ...
- increasing the student’s motivation
- methodological training for teachers
- increasing the number of Teachers and Students who speak a foreign language
Students typically enter the lower primary classes full of drive and an eagerness to learn but this tapers off during their years at school until, finally, it reaches low levels in the last years. Having a low level of motivation makes successful learning more difficult to achieve. The question is ’what can we, as Teachers, do to maintain and increase the students motivation.’
Our aims: 
- increasing our students’ learning efficiency through working with gifted students, training Students to develop and manage  
  effective, individual study schedules. Improving their levels of retentive memory and concentration will help them to do this.
- widening the methodology knowledge of staff as part of a programme of professional improvement
- development of digital competency
- encouraging competitions and connection with sport clubs 
- strengthening and widening international relationships
- intensifying co-operation between the staff members

Staff members contribute to expanding the Schools methodology knowledge by their job-shadowing activities which gives them insight into the methods used to motivate students in other educational establishments. Altogether 11 teachers, 6 from the lower primary, 4 from the higher primary and one from the management team will take part in this project. 6 of them will visit schools in 3 countries (the UK, Finland and Germany) following nearly a year of preparation spent getting to know these countries’ educational systems and effective motivation techniques; 3 teachers will take part in different vocational trainings and 2 will improve their English language knowledge in the UK.

The planned effects of the project:
- strong working relationship between the members of the project team
- improved working methods by increased methodological knowledge
- increasing the number of Teachers who read/speak/obtain knowledge through researching reference materials
- improving our working methods through increased methodological knowledge
- translating the knowledge we gain into an effective part of our own pedagogical programme
- our colleagues will strengthen professionally and mentally as well as developing increased energy reserves  as the work load in a 
   project of this nature is demanding.
- as the initial project progresses additional project elements will be generated
Bradford Central – Getting it Going Stage 2 CLLD
City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council (CBMDC)

Joint-funded with ESF, the project is the delivery of the Community Led Local Development (CLLD) Strategy for the Bradford Central area in Leeds City Region.  The value for money assessment is positive when the wider impacts of the project are considered.

The consortium partners will: 
a) Engage and consult with stakeholders in the 20% most deprived LSOAs (IMD 2010) in City, Great Horton and Manningham wards in Bradford Central through direct communications, events, and meetings in local venues. 
B) Establish the Local Action Group (LAG) involving local stakeholders. 
C) Undertake research with the community and business to identify issues and challenges to be addressed. 
D) Develop, consult on, and sign-off the strategy overseen by the LAG.
Bradford Central CLLD – Getting it Going
City of Bradford Metropolitan District Council (CBMDC)

Bradford Central CLLD Getting it Going is a 5 year programme of support for the most disadvantaged communities in Bradford. It will help people progress towards employment or entrepreneurship and business to grow by supporting local projects that address local issues.

The project will bring together 4 local organisations to work in partnership to undertake a number of planned activities. These include: EngagementPromotion of project and ESF/ERDF support to all stakeholders. of individuals from the target groups in City, Great Horton and Manningham wards of businesses and employers (of all sizes) based in or around the target wards of stakeholders that can enable the project to link to opportunities for businesses and the    communities in the target wards of community, voluntary and public organisations and groups, including training & education and business support intermediaries, who work within the area and can reach the target groups and businesses 
Consultation and Research: With stakeholders to identify potential members of LAG, and the target groups. 
With target groups and support stakeholders to identify issues, support needs, and opportunities: where, when, how and what, contributing to the strategy and interventions. 
With wider support stakeholders to map existing /planned delivery, identify gaps in support and needs not currently being addressed, and gain commitment to integrated working, ensuring non-duplication of activities and value for money. With all stakeholders to identify key risks and potential constraints to implementation of a CLLD strategy, and opportunities and interventions that can help overcome barriers. 
Additional desk-based research to provide additional data and intelligence about target groups and needs, and to identify good practice developed elsewhere, that could be customised to address specific issues and challenges. Local Action Group Establishment: 
Development of terms of reference and criteria for LAG, based on consultation
